awd_titl_txt: Black Hole Exhaust: Feedback and the Role of Radio Plasma in Galaxy Clusters
awd_abstract_narration:
Supermassive black holes located in the centers of massive, centrally-located cluster galaxies can serve as engines of powerful, magnetized jets that interact with the intracluster medium and can profoundly affect the flow of heat within the cluster and the formation of stars within the galaxy.  The actual physical mechanisms involved in these interactions between these jets and the host cluster are poorly understood and remain a major challenge to astrophysicists.  This project aims to perform magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) computer simulations with the goal of understanding how black holes stop clusters from cooling and how stable cluster atmospheres can be constructed that satisfy all observational requirements of temperature, entropy, field strength and topology and gas composition.  At the same time, this research will investigate how magnetized jets evolve self consistently in dynamic environments.  The proposed simulations will be the first generation of adaptive mesh refinement-MHD (AMR-MHD) simulations of resolved, ballistic jets in self-consistently evolved, realistic clusters.  The principal investigator (PI) will construct the first exhaustive parameter study on how radio galaxies evolve for a set of fundamental jet parameters that include magnetic fields.

Educationally, this project will provide funding and training of a postdoctoral research scientist and an undergraduate student.  In addition, the PI's public outreach activities include a web site for presenting and explaining this research to a general audience that will include videos of his public lecture series.

por.por_cntn:
At the very top of the food-chain of cosmic structure sit galaxy clusters, made of hundreds of galaxies and thousands of galaxy masses worth of hot gas and dark matter. They are important sign-posts for cosmic structure, and understanding them is crucial for understanding how the cosmos evolved from the big-bang to its current state. The hot gas that dominates the mix of ordinary matter in clusters emits enormous amounts of X-ray light, and the energy carried away by those X-rays should cause the cluter gas to cool, since the energy powering the X-rays comes for the heat energy of the gas. However, while we see the radiation, we do not see evidence for the expected drop in temperature. This discrepancy is called the cooling flow problem, and black holes are astronomer's current favorite explanation for it.

Massive galaxies like those found in galaxy clusters contain massive black holes, and these black holes launch powerful flows of ultra-hot plasma into their environment, bundled into tightly collimated bi-directional streams called jets. X-ray astronomers actually observe that these jets excavate enormous cavities in the cluster gas, filling them with magnetized plasma. The energy pumped into the cluster by this process is --- in principle --- sufficient to heat the cluster and explain the observed lack of cooling. The details of this heating process are, however, far from understood. Our program was aimed at illuminating the processes that lead to the inflation of cavities, with the goal of advancing our basic understanding of the dynamical processes within clusters.

The complexity of cluster physics requires massive computer simulations to model. The previous state-of-the-art in these simulations was solving the equations of fluid mechanics to study how jets propagate into clusters, but mostly neglecting the effects of magnetic fields. However, these magnetic effects are crutical for understanding how cavities and heating in clusters develop, both from a theoretical perspective (i.e., a magnetized cavity might behave very differently from an un-magnetized one) and from an observational point of view (the radio emission used to diagnose the content and structure of cavities depends crucially on the strength and structure of the magnetic fields that fill it).

In order to address the question of how magnetic fields affect the energy deposition in cluster cavities, we designed, ran, and analyzed a series of state-of-the-art high-resolution magneto-hydrodynamic simulations. We investigated how the topology (that is, the shape) of field lines in the jet affects the properties of cavities, showing that the degree to which the field is wound-up determines the shape of cavities, and their size and location in the cluster. This is critical for modeling and understanding the observational properties of cavities. It is also important for the efficiency of energy injection, as it affects the location where the energy is deposited, and whether it actually reaches the cold gas that is most in need of heating.

We also investigated how cavities, once they were inflated, are affected by shock waves through a process called the Richtmyer-Meshkov instability. Shocks are known to travel through galaxy clusters from time to time (every few hundred million years). This interaction must happen, and it is a poorly understood process. We ran a series of numerical magneto-hydrodynamic simulations that showed that magnetic fields have a modest effect on the efficiency with which cavities and shocks exchange energy, which suggests that the Richtmyer-Meshkov instability is a surprisingly efficient mechanism for shocks to deposit energy into clusters.

Overall, our work shows that magnetic fields must be taken into account if we want to understand the process of cosmic feedback in detail.
